questions.answer_description:
The vSAN components that reside on the magnetic disk or flash capacity device are marked as degraded.
Reference:
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.5/com.vmware.vsphere.virtualsan.doc/GUID-9A2DCE0B-CFA1-41C1-97CE-DA56A55426EA.html

discussion.content: C is right

comments.content:
For those confused between C and D and have every right to be as usch F** question, this KB should point to C being correct
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/com.vmware.vsphere.vsan-monitoring.doc/GUID-9A2DCE0B-CFA1-41C1-97CE-DA56A55426EA.html

discussion.content:
C is right

vSAN components are found in a variety of states:
• Active components: Healthy and functioning correctly.
• Reconfiguring components: In the process of applying storage policy changes.
• Absent components: No longer available due to a failure.
• Stale components: No longer in sync with other components of the same vSAN object.
• Degraded components: Not expected to return due to a detected failure.

So, absent appears when a Maintenance operation is done in the vSAN cluster

Another bad question. Inaccessible can be absent or degraded. See the VMware article below.
https://blogs.vmware.com/virtualblocks/2017/11/09/understanding-vsan-rebuilds/

comments.content:
Absent means that the component is still there, it will be back later but not gone away.

A component is in absent state if vSAN detects a temporary component failure where the component might recover and restore its working state.

So answer is C, degraded.

discussion.content:
D is correct answer 
capacity disk inacesible means disk was removed from host and VSAN believes that component re-appear )
https://cormachogan.com/2014/12/04/vsan-part-30-difference-between-absent-degraded-components/

maybe D.
"Inaccessible" situation is occurred by manually detaching capacity disk.
In this case, there is no reply. and status should be "absent".

Answer C is right:

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.vsan-monitoring.doc/GUID-3863B640-3449-46A2-84E0-AC07E5A604FD.html

comments.content:
vSAN examines whether the hosts and the capacity devices can satisfy the requirements for space and placement rules for the objects on the failed device or disk group. If such a host with capacity is available, vSAN starts the recovery process immediately because the components are marked as degraded.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.vsan-monitoring.doc/GUID-9A2DCE0B-CFA1-41C1-97CE-DA56A55426EA.html

questions.question_text: How are components marked on a capacity device that is inaccessible?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
is correct
C easy give away Question

C is right.

To prepare the environment for encryption, you must set up a key management server (KMS) or cluster.
The KMS has the following characteristics:
• Must be compatible with Key Management Interoperability Protocol (KMIP) 1.1
• Provides a KMS for KMIP clients, such as vCenter Server
• Can be configured with a KMIP proxy server
• Is accessed over IP

Taken from vSAN 6.7 Deploy and Manage Lecture Manual - About the Key Management Server section
C is right
C: https://storagehub.vmware.com/t/vsan-6-7-u-3-proof-of-concept-guide-1/vsan-encryption-requirements/

questions.question_text:
An administrator is configuring vSAN Encryption on an existing hybrid cluster. During the configuration, the administrator is unable to see any information for the
Key Management Server (KMS) cluster in the dropdown menu.
What is necessary for the KMS cluster options to populate?

choices.C: The Key Management Server needs to be added to vCenter.
choices.D: vSAN encryption is enabled at the VM level by storage policies.
choices.B: vSAN encryption needs to be enabled during the creation of a new vSAN cluster.

questions.answer_description:
To tolerate n failures, you need 2n + 1 ESXi host in the vSAN cluster.
Reference:
https://searchvmware.techtarget.com/answer/How-can-a-VM-storage-policy-improve-vSAN-cluster-redundancy

discussion.content:
C is correct.
"Minimum host requirements for mirroring as a failure tolerance method used an algorithm of 2n+1 where an is the number of Failures to Tolerate."
https://storagehub.vmware.com/t/vsan-space-efficiency-technologies/host-requirements-1/

Selected Answer: C
C easy give away

comments.content: it says minimum so the it should be 2n+1

discussion.content: it is an ambiguous question in the case of RADI5/6 the formula is 2n+2
C is correct

C is correct.

• For n failures that are tolerated, n+1 copies of the object are created.
• For n failures that are tolerated, 2n+1 hosts contributing storage are required.
• Default value: 1.

Taken from vSAN 6.7 Deploy and Manage Lecture Manual - Level of Failures to Tolerate section

Copies of data = 2n+1. 
Number of hosts needed is = n+1
2n+1 is gold rule
since this is minimum... the answer should be n+1.

questions.question_text: What is the formula for determining the minimum number of vSAN hosts in a cluster necessary to support a Failures To Tolerate (FTT) policy, where FTT=n?

A virtual machine is unable to access one of its virtual disks.
Which vSAN Health check should an administrator view to troubleshoot the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct
A for sure
Agree with A
A is right.
For sure C and E, no way D as vSAN dont care much as max required is 32GB

comments.content:
C&E is correct Answer as On monitor tab, in Used capacity breakdown there is dropdown for Group by (Data type & object type).

you are correct if we want to calculate capacity but question is not that.

discussion.content: I think it should be C and D. Amount of memory determines the swap file size. If you have 200 VM's with 4 Gb of non reserved memory, it takes up 800 Gb of storage.
C&E is correct

questions.question_text: Which two group types are used to determine capacity breakdown in a vSAN datastore? (Choose two.)
